Google announces Family Link, a tool for creating and managing Google accounts for kids under 13 Ryan Whitwam Follow View All Posts 2017/03/15 9:55am PDTMar 15, 2017 123 Plus 1 on G+ 311 Share on Facebook 92 Share on Twitter Total Shares526 Google News Google has never allowed anyone under the age of 13 to have a Google account, and certainly no one would ever lie about their age on the internet. Right? Well, now you don't have to lie with the new Family Link app. Family Link (invite-only and US-only for now) lets you create a Google account for your under-13 offspring with advanced parental controls built-in. There are some caveats, but this seems like a tool many parents will be anxious to check out. Setting up a Family Link account for your kid can only be done through the Family Link app, which is also what you use to manage the account and monitor device activity. One major drawback is that your child needs to be using a Nougat phone, but you can use Family Link to tightly control that device. It includes screen time tracking, bedtime schedules, and app rating limits.¬†When setting up an account, you will be asked to pay $0.30. This isn't a blatant cash grab by Google‚Äîthe FTC requires verifiable parental consent when collecting personal information about kids, and credit card payments are the easiest approved method. You could "object" to collection after seeing the charge on your account. Family Link is only for kids under the age of 13, but you have options as soon as the child hits that age. Parents and kids can keep using Family Link if they¬†like. However, Google will reach out and give the birthday boy or girl the option of transitioning to a regular Google account, over which their parents¬†have no control. I imagine most will take Google up on that offer. I hear teenagers are rebellious. If you want to check out Family Link, request an invite from the landing page. There's also some additional legal info you can review if you're feeling a little skittish about feeding your child's data into the gaping maw of Google. Source: Google Tags apps Family Link Google kids parental controls subscribe ... Previous Story Google is testing a new interface for the Google Search app ... Server-side tests have broken Google Now and the Play Store for some users Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 5:53pm PDTMay 6, 2017 26 Plus 1 on G+ 51 Share on Facebook 46 Share on Twitter Total Shares123 Applications Google News Google regularly conducts server-side tests - showing new features and UI changes to only a handful of users at a time. Unfortunately, sometimes these have adverse affects on users. In this case, Google has broken the Play Store and Google Now for some users, as a result of two independent server-side tests. The Play Store test, according to one report on the Google Play Help Forum, removes everything from the app's home page. Apps can still be searched for and installed, and updating applications works fine, but the front page is completely blank. There does not appear to be any fix for this right now - if you have it, you're stuck with it until Google figures it out. Another test completely breaks Google Now cards, with the main Now screen showing a generic error message. Luckily, there is a way to fix this one. Simply open¬†your Settings app, go to the Application Manager, find the Google app, tap 'Manage Storage,' and finally press 'Clear Google Search Data.' Between this, the recent Google Drive for Windows mishap, and the dogfood update that was pushed to normal users, I think Google is forgetting that most people¬†don't want to be beta (or alpha) testers. Source: Reddit (1, 2), Google Play Help Forum Tags Google google now play store server tests server-side test server-side tests subscribe ... Server-side tests have broken Google Now and the Play Store for some users Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 5:53pm PDTMay 6, 2017 26 Plus 1 on G+ 51 Share on Facebook 46 Share on Twitter Total Shares123 Applications Google News Google regularly conducts server-side tests - showing new features and UI changes to only a handful of users at a time. Unfortunately, sometimes these have adverse affects on users. In this case, Google has broken the Play Store and Google Now for some users, as a result of two independent server-side tests. The Play Store test, according to one report on the Google Play Help Forum, removes everything from the app's home page. Apps can still be searched for and installed, and updating applications works fine, but the front page is completely blank. There does not appear to be any fix for this right now - if you have it, you're stuck with it until Google figures it out. Another test completely breaks Google Now cards, with the main Now screen showing a generic error message. Luckily, there is a way to fix this one. Simply open¬†your Settings app, go to the Application Manager, find the Google app, tap 'Manage Storage,' and finally press 'Clear Google Search Data.' Between this, the recent Google Drive for Windows mishap, and the dogfood update that was pushed to normal users, I think Google is forgetting that most people¬†don't want to be beta (or alpha) testers. Source: Reddit (1, 2), Google Play Help Forum Tags Google google now play store server tests server-side test server-side tests subscribe ... Indiatimes|The Times of India|The Economic Times : HI, My Times LOGOUTSign In City More Beauty Pageants Photos Videos More Fashion Specials Debate Photos Videos Platinum Times of India More HomeHome Videos City India World Business Tech Cricket Sports Entertainment TV Life & Style Photos TIMES NEWS - RADIO Elections 2017 Delhi MCD 2017 Brandwire Yearender 2016 Good Governance City METRO CITIES Mumbai Delhi Bangalore Hyderabad Kolkata Chennai OTHER CITIES Agartala Agra Imphal Ahmedabad Allahabad Amritsar Aurangabad Bareilly Bhopal Bhubaneswar Chandigarh Coimbatore Cuttack Dehradun Erode Faridabad Goa Gurgaon Guwahati Hubli Indore Jaipur Jammu Jamshedpur Jind Kanpur Kochi Kolhapur Kozhikode Lucknow Ludhiana Madurai Mangalore Meerut Mysore Nagpur Nashik Navi Mumbai Noida Patna Puducherry Pune Raipur Rajahmundry Rajkot Ranchi Srinagar Salem Shillong Shimla Surat Thane Trichy Thiruvananthapuram Vadodara Varanasi Visakhapatnam Pune Crime Civic Issues Politics Schools & Colleges Events Delhi MCD Polls 2017 ALL News ¬ª City News ¬ª Pune News ¬ª Pitroda: Onus for content is on Google, FB Pitroda: Onus for content is on Google, FB Companies such as Google, Facebook and other social media platforms should take responsibility for content on their sites, technocrat and policymaker Sam Pitroda said on Saturday.TNN | Updated: May 7, 2017, 08.36 AM IST PUNE: Companies such as Google, Facebook and other social media platforms should take responsibility for content on their sites, technocrat and policymaker Sam Pitroda said on Saturday. He and a few other individuals across the globe have come together under the aegis of Association for Accountability and Internet Democracy (AAID) in Paris to demand "protection of private integrity and societal value" on the Internet. "Twenty of us from all over the world have come together and we want big companies like Facebook and Google to take responsibility for their content," Pitroda said while addressing a gathering of Pune International Centre members and others at the College of Engineering here. He said unlike newspapers, big companies like Google and Facebook do not take responsibility for their content. "If newspapers publish incorrect information, they will apologise. On the other hand, Google and Facebook won't even remove the content. So, this has been bothering us for quite some time," he said. Pitroda said that there is concern over a lot of misinformation, gossip and vendetta on social media. "By design, people propagate misinformation because it gets them more hits," the technology veteran added. The man, who also served as advisor to former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, said some people hire publicists to tweet on their behalf. "There is a difference between propaganda and information," said the man who is credited with laying the telecommunication roadmap for the country in the 1980s. He stressed the need for a new design to the world order in the Internet age and said India - because of its value system, family bonds and social cohesion - is best suited to build that design. "World can only be redesigned by Indians but we are not ready to take on a task like this because our house is not in order. Today, the world is waiting for India to take the lead. People want family values, love, compassion -- all of which India has and also it has costumes, colour, food, diversity. No other country has that kind of diversity. To hold a country with so much diversity without guns is one of India's greatest accomplishments," he added. Stay updated on the go with Times of India News App. Click here to download it for your device. Google is "currently exploring solutions" for connecting existing Google accounts to Family Link Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 7:09pm PDTMay 6, 2017 19 Plus 1 on G+ 44 Share on Facebook 40 Share on Twitter Total Shares103 Google News Back in March, Google launched 'Family Link,' a way for parents to create and manage Google accounts for their children (13 or younger). The feature ended up being very impressive, but had two huge limitations - it only worked on Android 7.0 or higher, and you couldn't use existing Google accounts for your kids. Thankfully, Google is working on a possible solution for the second problem. The company¬†has updated a support page for Family Link with the below message: You can only use Family Link's parental supervision features with Google Accounts created using Family Link. We've heard from many people that they'd like to use an existing Google Account with Family Link, and we're currently exploring solutions. That's better than nothing, I suppose. I can understand why it might take more time to make that functionality work - in addition to the possible technical issues, Google has¬†to follow all government guidelines related to online accounts for minors. Source: Google Support Tags Family Link Google google account subscribe ... Previous Story Server-side tests have broken Google Now and the Play Store for some users ... What if your kid is currently 15 and has used their account for years now but you want to bring them in? There's at least a 5 year phase in period based on that alone. But also, even if everyone follows the 13 rule, what if your kid makes it on their 13th birthday, but you just aren't aware of this yet then want to add it in. The option to roll that account into it is definitely handy. C√©dric B It could also be an account 100% managed by the parent. For now my daughter uses my account when she plays, watches YouTube,... I think I should instead open another account for such purposes (and family link is not yet available in france). Even Google made a tv ad where a dad created an account for his newborn, then added in it emails,... that the daughter would get later. The Google Home has a built-in library of relaxing ambient audio Paul Quinn Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 7:26am PDTMay 6, 2017 37 Plus 1 on G+ 56 Share on Facebook 55 Share on Twitter Total Shares148 Google Home Videos Update¬†1: 2017/05/06 10:12am PDT While Google's support page says the feature is limited to Google Homes in United States, there are reports of it working outside 'Murica as well. Feeling like you want to relax after you've finished that meal you prepared with Google Home's help? Overwhelmed by your Home's answer to what's on your schedule tomorrow? Just ask it¬†to help you relax with some soothing ambient sounds. Currently offering a catalog of 15 different ambient sound themes, Google Home can now replace your sound machine. The ambient sound themes include nature sounds, water sounds, fireplace sounds, and country sounds. The latter of those is crickets, lots of crickets. The ocean sounds theme must be based on heavy seas because I found that one a little too stimulating. If you're feeling lucky (that's Google Play Music lingo), you can just say, "Help me relax," and your Google Home will select a theme for you. Do you want to fall asleep to relaxing sounds? No problem. You can tell your Google Home to play one of these relaxing themes for a specified amount of time. For example, you can say, "Hey Google, play forest sounds for two hours." You'll hear the sounds of the forest for two hours, and then your Home will slowly fade out the audio. If you don't specify a time limit, it will default to one hour. Google has even included this helpful video on their support page. Let Tech With Brett take it away. Google notes that you can press and hold your finger on the top of the device to activate your Google Home instead of speaking the wake word. I'm not sure what the advantage of this is because you still need to speak your request to play an ambient sound theme. If you are going to talk to your Home anyway, you might as well wake it with your voice too. I can already imagine combining these sounds with Hue lighting scenes to create my own voice activated relaxation chamber. Source: Google Update¬†1: 2017/05/06 10:12am PDT While Google's support page says the feature is limited to Google Homes in United States, there are reports of it working outside 'Murica as well. Google is "currently exploring solutions" for connecting existing Google accounts to Family Link Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 7:09pm PDTMay 6, 2017 19 Plus 1 on G+ 44 Share on Facebook 40 Share on Twitter Total Shares103 Google News Back in March, Google launched 'Family Link,' a way for parents to create and manage Google accounts for their children (13 or younger). The feature ended up being very impressive, but had two huge limitations - it only worked on Android 7.0 or higher, and you couldn't use existing Google accounts for your kids. Thankfully, Google is working on a possible solution for the second problem. The company¬†has updated a support page for Family Link with the below message: You can only use Family Link's parental supervision features with Google Accounts created using Family Link. We've heard from many people that they'd like to use an existing Google Account with Family Link, and we're currently exploring solutions. That's better than nothing, I suppose. I can understand why it might take more time to make that functionality work - in addition to the possible technical issues, Google has¬†to follow all government guidelines related to online accounts for minors. Source: Google Support Tags Family Link Google google account subscribe ... Previous Story Server-side tests have broken Google Now and the Play Store for some users ... Server-side tests have broken Google Now and the Play Store for some users Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 5:53pm PDTMay 6, 2017 26 Plus 1 on G+ 51 Share on Facebook 46 Share on Twitter Total Shares123 Applications Google News Google regularly conducts server-side tests - showing new features and UI changes to only a handful of users at a time. Unfortunately, sometimes these have adverse affects on users. In this case, Google has broken the Play Store and Google Now for some users, as a result of two independent server-side tests. The Play Store test, according to one report on the Google Play Help Forum, removes everything from the app's home page. Apps can still be searched for and installed, and updating applications works fine, but the front page is completely blank. There does not appear to be any fix for this right now - if you have it, you're stuck with it until Google figures it out. Another test completely breaks Google Now cards, with the main Now screen showing a generic error message. Luckily, there is a way to fix this one. Simply open¬†your Settings app, go to the Application Manager, find the Google app, tap 'Manage Storage,' and finally press 'Clear Google Search Data.' Between this, the recent Google Drive for Windows mishap, and the dogfood update that was pushed to normal users, I think Google is forgetting that most people¬†don't want to be beta (or alpha) testers. Source: Reddit (1, 2), Google Play Help Forum Tags Google google now play store server tests server-side test server-side tests subscribe ... 9to5Mac 9to5Toys Electrek Community About Tips/Contact Search Android Chrome/OS Guides Android Android Wear Android Auto Nexus Chromebook Google Apps Android TV YouTube Trending in Google Best Android smartwatches you can buy [May¬†2017] Trending in Google Best Android phones you can buy [May¬†2017] Trending in Google Review: The BlackBerry Keyone is a step back in time that I really want to love¬†[Video] Trending in Google Review: Acer Chromebook 11 N7 is a rugged, affordable laptop for students¬†[Video] Trending in Google These are the smart home products I‚Äôm using with Google¬†Home Trending in Google Review: Samsung Galaxy S8 brings a familiar formula even nearer to perfection¬†[Video] Today GOOG: 927.13 -4.53 Some users reporting ‚Äòfailed to load cards‚Äô issue with Google Now, here‚Äôs how to fix it [Update: Google Play¬†too] Ben Schoon - May. 6th 2017 4:49 pm PT @NexusBen Android Google Now View Comments Facebook Twitter Google Pinterest Reddit Google Now is an incredibly convenient¬†service, and many have come to rely on it pretty heavily. Currently, though, there seems to be an issue with the service, rendering it useless to affected users. Thankfully, though, a temporary fix is available. The best gifts for Android users Update: Android Police has been able to trace the cause of this issue back to a server-side test, as well as confirming the same cause for a Google Play bug that removes all content from the main screen. Since this is a server-side¬†test, not all phones or accounts will be affected, but users who are will likely have to sit tight until Google resolves things. According to several users on a growing Reddit thread, multiple users on Twitter, as well as both myself and my colleague Abner Li, Google Now has been having some issues for the past few days. For reasons unknown, the service refuses the cards that give it its functionality, instead simply showing the message ‚Äúfailed to load cards,‚Äù regardless of the network connection. For me, the issue has only been appearing on my Pixel XL (Android 7.1.2), not my Galaxy S8 or my Huawei Mate 9. Looking at user reports on Reddit, Pixel and Nexus devices seem to be the most affected, with some other miscellaneous devices, including the Galaxy S8, seeing the same issue. It also isn‚Äôt happening solely in the US, with reports coming from multiple regions around the globe including the UK. Thankfully, though, one Reddit user has a working fix for the problem. Simply clearing the Google app‚Äôs data seems to eliminate the issue. To do this, simply go into Settings > Application Manager > Google App > Manage Space > Clear Google Search Data. Once you‚Äôve done that, your cards should start working again. Ben Schoon @NexusBen Ben is a writer for 9to5Google who can also be found over on the 9to5Google YouTube channel and on Twitter @NexusBen. Name: Subject: Message: People are using more apps now than ever before Newsby Joe Hindy6 hours ago 3 201 16 The rhetoric regarding apps hasn‚Äôt changed much over the years. Every year, people are using more and more¬†for longer periods of time. As it turns out, 2016 wasn‚Äôt much different. According to a report by App Annie, people spent nearly one trillion hours in apps in 2016. That trend is looking to continue into 2017. Let‚Äôs take a look at the latest numbers and¬†dive more into the topic. Related Articles: ¬† App Annie: For the first time, Android app spending will ...March 30, 2017 The first graph shows that people used apps 25% more often in Q1 2016 than the previous quarter. App Annie hypothesizes that it‚Äôs because the smartphone user base has grown so substantially. More phones are coming out in more places that didn‚Äôt previously have smartphones. Thus, the conclusion isn‚Äôt that people are using apps more often. Rather, there are simply more people using apps than there were before. The graph above doesn‚Äôt seem like it adds up to almost one trillion hours. However, keep in mind that this graph is just for Android phones. As it turns out, virtually all of us have apps that we don‚Äôt normally use. On average, we only use between 1/3 and 1/2 of the apps we have installed on any given month (based on region). There are a variety of reasons why this could be. Many devices have pre-installed apps that people simply never use. Additionally, apps like file managers, background downloaders, and other productivity types may see infrequent use. For instance, many people use Google Docs, but how many have downloaded Slides and Sheets and then only occasionally use them? App Annie mentions the importance of retention as a measurement of success. After all, the most successful apps are the ones people actually use. In every region they measured, App Annie was unable to find a demographic that doesn‚Äôt use at least nine different apps per day. Most had over ten apps used per day. That seems like a lot. However, if you take into account that virtually everything you do in a phone requires an app, the numbers add up quickly. The report notes that the app types used every day vary widely as well. Thus, it‚Äôs not just communication and social media, but also productivity, tools, utilities, shopping, entertainment, and others. The conclusion is that we aren‚Äôt just using a bunch of apps every day, but rather that we‚Äôre using a bunch of different types every day. Based on the graph above, people use four different tools and four communication apps per month. App Annie posits that this is likely because of pre-installed apps that people actually do use. Google Chrome on Android, Safari on iOS, etc. It‚Äôs also worth mentioning that Cortana and Google Assistant fall under the tools category and they count as¬†well. Android users play more games than iOS users do. However, iOS users use a larger variety of social media platforms than Android users. The important thing to note for this, though, is how many different varieties of apps that people use every month. On average, people in the United States spend one month out of every year using an app of some sort. That averages out to about two hours and 15 minutes per day. In fact, the amount of time spent per day has increased every year since 2015. Really, there isn‚Äôt a lot of additional analysis here. It‚Äôs another graph that shows that people are spending more time using their phones. App Annie‚Äôs research concluded that most people spent over 80% of their time not in the top app in their country. The top app in any given country is usually Facebook or WhatsApp. App Annie states¬†that this means that other app developers have plenty of time. However, we feel like there is more to it than that. For instance, a person may check Facebook many times a day for a minute at a time. On the other hand, Google Maps may only be opened once for ten minutes for the daily commute. We would love to see a ‚Äúper session‚Äù metric as well to see how often and how long people spend in an app every time they visit for a more complete view of peoples daily activity. App Annie did provide a graph to show the number of sessions per day and time per session. Most of this makes a lot of sense. Transportation had fewer sessions per day but more time per session. Likewise, finance had more sessions per day, but less time per session. After all, it doesn‚Äôt take but a few moments to check your bank balance. Social media is curiously absent from the graph. We imagine that‚Äôs because people use them for more sessions per day than this graph is set up to handle. Dating is a surprising case with both high sessions per day and minutes per session. The final image deals with gaming. Like apps, gaming has been on the rise for a few years. South Korea and Japan have the most gaming growth by a long shot. We‚Äôve known that games were on the rise for years. Especially since they draw in so much more revenue than apps do. None of it is really surprising, but it‚Äôs nice to see a graph of it. Check out the best Android apps, ever! ¬† 15 best Android apps of 20176 days ago The big takeaway here is that the apps and games market on mobile has taken hold. It‚Äôs not a commentary on how many apps get downloaded. After all, reports show that those numbers are going down in developed markets. What it does say is that the apps that people have chosen to use are ones they now use instead of previous methods in the past. We use apps to check our bank accounts, talk to people, navigate, and be productive more now than we did last year or the year before. For now, there is nothing to indicate that those trends are changing anytime soon. SUBSCRIBE Full RSS Feed Latest News Feed Entertainment News Feed Tech Feed World News Gaming Feed Sports Feed Funny & Strange Feed Health Feed Lifestyle Feed BuzzWorthy Feed Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Delivered To Your INBOX Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Email Address Or follow us online Facebook Twitter Google-plus Rss Google Docs Phishing Scam: How You Should Protect Yourself Technology 1 0 0 May 6, 2017 Google Docs Phishing Scam: How You Should Protect Yourself Chanel Adams Many Google Docs users were shocked to find a suspicious email in their inbox. Some were aware of deleting the email right away. Others, not so lucky. This prompted Google to warn users about a Google Docs phishing scam that may pop up in your inbox. This email invited the user to look at a Google Doc with a link that phished for the user‚Äôs personal information. Google handled the incident quickly. The tech giant also disabled features that were created to steal your personal information, reports USA Today. The incident made people aware that Google Docs is not as safe as it may look. It will also the change the way people will use and collaborate with the free word-processing tool. It‚Äôs also important for you to make sure that you‚Äôre using Google Docs the right away. The Google Docs phishing scam included an email saying that the user is invited to ‚Äúedit the following document.‚Äù The recipient sees a form generated by a company that claims to be from Google. Some of the users weren‚Äôt sure if the email was legitimate or not. When you click on the link, the hackers will get access to your Google account and all the information you have stored. [Image by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images] Here are some smart ways to use Google Docs. Google offers the option to include a ‚Äúshareable link‚Äù at the top. Use that option instead of generating the typical Google form email. Copy the link, compose your email, and send it to your friends, explaining what‚Äôs in the link and why they should open it. The Google Docs phishing scam included no context or note. It also didn‚Äôt even include the official blue Google Docs logo. Enable Google‚Äôs two-factor authentication. This will protect you from potential hackers. Signing in twice will make it harder for hackers to access your account. Google‚Äôs two-step process starts by signing in with your password. The second step involves receiving a text message code or authorizing via your Google app on your smartphone. Google also has an Authenticator app for signing in. Here are some additional Google Docs security tips from BetterCloud. You can limit sharing options in your Google Apps Control Panel. You also have options to set the link to private, with the domain, within the domain with a link, anyone with the link, and public on the web. [Image by Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images] You also want to make sure that your Gmail settings are safe as well. Google Docs is a great way to collaborate with your colleagues and coworkers via email. But it can pose some safety issues, as you can see. You don‚Äôt want to risk having your Gmail account compromised. Make sure you have a strong password. If you don‚Äôt, you may want to change it now or after reading this article. You also want to check your Gmail settings to ensure no one else has access to your emails. In addition, updating your web browser and reporting scams, spam, and phishing will keep your account safe and secure. While signing into your Google accounts is easy and quick, it‚Äôs just as important to sign out of them as well. Be careful whenever you‚Äôre using a network you don‚Äôt know, and learn more about setting up your home router and WiFi network securely. Lock your smartphone screen or device before you leave the house. Always keep your devices clean with anti-virus software and malware. Be sure to use safety measures when shopping online, especially on Google Shopping. Don‚Äôt use the same password that you use on your Google accounts. And, make sure to sign out of your account when you‚Äôre done with your online shopping. These are just some of the ways that you can take control of your Google Docs, Gmail, and other Google accounts. [Featured Image by Ethan Miller/Getty Images] Now Read This: ‚ÄòPrey‚Äô Reviews Are Rolling In ‚Äî What Do Critics Have To Say? The Google Home has a built-in library of relaxing ambient audio Paul Quinn Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 7:26am PDTMay 6, 2017 37 Plus 1 on G+ 56 Share on Facebook 55 Share on Twitter Total Shares148 Google Home Videos Update¬†1: 2017/05/06 10:12am PDT While Google's support page says the feature is limited to Google Homes in United States, there are reports of it working outside 'Murica as well. Feeling like you want to relax after you've finished that meal you prepared with Google Home's help? Overwhelmed by your Home's answer to what's on your schedule tomorrow? Just ask it¬†to help you relax with some soothing ambient sounds. Currently offering a catalog of 15 different ambient sound themes, Google Home can now replace your sound machine. The ambient sound themes include nature sounds, water sounds, fireplace sounds, and country sounds. The latter of those is crickets, lots of crickets. The ocean sounds theme must be based on heavy seas because I found that one a little too stimulating. If you're feeling lucky (that's Google Play Music lingo), you can just say, "Help me relax," and your Google Home will select a theme for you. Do you want to fall asleep to relaxing sounds? No problem. You can tell your Google Home to play one of these relaxing themes for a specified amount of time. For example, you can say, "Hey Google, play forest sounds for two hours." You'll hear the sounds of the forest for two hours, and then your Home will slowly fade out the audio. If you don't specify a time limit, it will default to one hour. Google has even included this helpful video on their support page. Let Tech With Brett take it away. Google notes that you can press and hold your finger on the top of the device to activate your Google Home instead of speaking the wake word. I'm not sure what the advantage of this is because you still need to speak your request to play an ambient sound theme. If you are going to talk to your Home anyway, you might as well wake it with your voice too. I can already imagine combining these sounds with Hue lighting scenes to create my own voice activated relaxation chamber. Source: Google Update¬†1: 2017/05/06 10:12am PDT While Google's support page says the feature is limited to Google Homes in United States, there are reports of it working outside 'Murica as well. MSPU Windows Phone Windows 10 Surface Xbox Enterprise Tip us Settings Text Input: Windows 10 Windows Phone Surface Xbox Reviews Settings Tip us Forum Text Input: Google exec says those famous last words about Windows 10 S -7 by Surur¬† @mspoweruser May 6, 2017 at 23:21 GMT8 hours ago Windows 10 S is the first Google-free Windows PC. ¬†The PC will not let users install Google Chrome, won‚Äôt let users change the default search engine to Google, and of course, does not have any Google Apps in the store (largely due to Google and not Microsoft.) Google is however pretty sanguine regarding Microsoft‚Äôs new OS, saying those famous last words which usually precedes being steam-rollered by the competition. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to see a validation of the approach we‚Äôve taken,‚Äù said Prabhakar Raghavan, the Google vice-president responsible for G Suite ‚Äî Google‚Äôs range of productivity apps like Docs and Pages. ‚ÄúWhat educational institutions have demanded is simplicity. It‚Äôs a real test tube for all of us, whether it‚Äôs Microsoft or any of us, right.‚Äù According to the latest stats, Google has grabbed 58% market share in the US education market, largely due to the low cost and easy manageability of Chromebooks and the browser-based curriculum which is somewhat unique to the USA. Microsoft has however taken pains to make sure their¬†Windows 10 S PCs were in the same price range as Chromebooks, and have even made sure the Edge browser is compatible with Google‚Äôs Education apps. The battle for the hearts and minds of students is important if Microsoft is to have any role in the computing lives of the next generation in 5 to 10 years. Noted Google‚Äôs Raghavan: ‚ÄúBecause kids do things in amazing ways where you or I would never expect. So here‚Äôs one of the things we‚Äôve learned in a study of kids as we were developing all our tools for classrooms, right. We would put a Chromebook in front of a kid, they would whip out their phone and write their essay. We said ‚Äòno no no, there‚Äôs a keyboard there, you can use it,‚Äô and they still write the essay there. They said ‚Äòwe‚Äôll use the keyboard to touch up the formatting, but it‚Äôll be much faster here,‚Äô right. This is something we consistently learned when we looked at pre-teens ‚Ä¶ these kids are really forerunners, the vanguards of human evolution, in some sense, and so it‚Äôs great to see that some of the approaches we‚Äôve taken, but I think the world is going to keep evolving and it‚Äôs a scramble for us to keep up with what people are going to do.‚Äù With no mobile platform to speak of the success of Windows 10 S in schools is even more important for Microsoft. ‚ÄúThe success of the Chromebook has awakened sleeping giants,‚Äù Tyler Bosmeny, CEO of education tech company Clever, told Reuters. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much investment into the space ‚Äî it‚Äôs unlike anything I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù Whether Microsoft has what it takes to convince educators to take up their platform remains to be seen, but it is probably a bad idea to bet against¬†Microsoft in the semi-corporate environment¬†of the education industry. Opinion: Even if you can, you probably shouldn't buy a Google Pixel anymore David Ruddock Follow View All Posts 2017/05/01 2:09pm PDTMay 1, 2017 103 Plus 1 on G+ 370 Share on Facebook 104 Share on Twitter Total Shares577 Editorials Pixel Pixel XL The Google Pixel is a notoriously hard phone to get a hold of. Persistent stock issues have plagued Google's first "in-house" handset from day one, and things really are little to no better six months after the launch event. Honestly, it's a bit embarrassing just how consistently incompetent Google seems to be at keeping a reasonable inventory of phones available for purchase. But setting that aside, as one of the Pixel's most ardent evangelists, I think there's something it's probably time for me to come clean on: Even if you could buy a Pixel today, I really think you shouldn't. The Pixel is a product with generation-one product issues. The Bluetooth performance is horrid. It's not waterproof. The bezels really are due for a shrink. I don't think the exterior coating on the black and blue variants is of a particularly high quality. The glass window gets scuffed up incredibly easily. The Snapdragon 821 is officially old news. And it doesn't support proper advanced network features across all four of the big US carriers. There are other flaws I could point to, and while none of them are too terrible, they do speak to the slightly-rushed development cycle this phone seems to have been subjected to. Sure, Google got some things astoundingly¬†right: the performance, the camera, the larger software experience. In fact, I think the Pixel is easily the best Android smartphone ever for these strengths, at least if we're talking about me personally as a user (your mileage, obviously, may vary). But for all the great, smooth, fast, clean, pure, simple, natural, and various other adjective-members singing in the Pixel-praise cavalcade, this phone is not the one to buy right now. For starters, Google continues to ask what is an increasingly laughable amount of money for the model most of us want - the 128GB XL - at a staggering $870. Sure, Apple charges the same for an iPhone 7 Plus 128GB, but I'm under no illusion that this comparison in any way favors Google. The iPhone comes with Apple customer service (with actual stores), a longer software support period going forward, and runs no real risk of poor resale value. The Pixel? Google's online support is iffy at best, we know the phone will be unsupported by October 2018, and I have a strong feeling generation-one Pixel resale values will drop like a rock once the new phones are announced. And that really is why, if you haven't pulled the trigger on a Pixel yet, you should just wait. It's overpriced, under-supported, and competing phones like the Galaxy S8 offer a whole lot more technology for your money. The Galaxy S8+ is $20 less than a 128GB Pixel XL, and I would argue it is far and away the better smartphone value. That amazing display, brand-new Snapdragon 835 processor, jaw-dropping design and packaging, and the full support of all our American carriers' latest LTE advancements could each be a reason on its own to put the Galaxy S8 above Google's smartphone. Do I still prefer using the Pixel over the S8? Sure. But I wouldn't buy a 128GB Pixel XL over a Galaxy S8+ today. That would be, frankly, a bit silly. If Google was asking $670 and not $870, the discussion would probably change, but they aren't. You've got to pay full price, and there's no way I could recommend anyone do that. If you're still on the fence about the Pixel, let me try to push you over: wait for the next generation. I realize that this sort of thinking can devolve into a rationale that encourages you to never upgrade anything because something newer, faster, and better is constantly on the horizon. But in this case, I think it's a consideration that is worth weighing more seriously than usual. Many of the Pixel's biggest flaws relate to Google's inexperience producing a smartphone. Issues that only come up as you try to mass-produce and distribute a product with a real marketing campaign that creates real demand, and the phone gets into the hands of "real" users who aren't part of the now-derailed Nexus phone hypetrain. Inside Google, expectations were no doubt managed, realities realized, and priorities accordingly re-calibrated after this first launch. (Side note: if the Bluetooth performance on the next Pixel is as bad as the first one, I may scream, Google.) Meanwhile, the things that make the Pixel great aren't going anywhere. The next Pixel will be fast, it will take great photos, and it will offer a wonderfully unfettered Android experience. Those that make it less than great? Google is no doubt drilling down through the worst of them in order to ensure the Pixel 2 - or whatever it's called - won't¬†make the same mistakes that the original did (waterproofing, please). And one of the primary reasons to try the Pixel in the first place - to be on the very bleeding edge - really only remains true from a software standpoint. Older phones like the Nexus 5X and 6P don't even let the Pixel have an advantage there, as they're on the same update track until around the time the next Pixel phones launch. If you absolutely need a smartphone soon and the Pixel is tempting you, ask yourself this: Can you deal with a Moto G5 Plus for six months if it means having a better Pixel down the road? While as a reviewer I have the admitted luxury of not needing to consider such things, were I in such a position, I'd have little in the way of a counterargument to offer. Sure, you'll take a resale hit on anything you buy now, but the Pixel is going to face a much, much steeper devaluation curve in that time than any budget phone. Buying a Pixel right now just doesn't make sense. I love my Pixel XL, but I'm officially done recommending the phone to friends and relatives. Instead, I'll tell them to wait, or to get the Galaxy S8 they were probably going to buy anyway. Tags editorial google pixel google pixel xl opinion pixel xl subscribe ... Opinion: Even if you can, you probably shouldn't buy a Google Pixel anymore David Ruddock Follow View All Posts 2017/05/01 2:09pm PDTMay 1, 2017 103 Plus 1 on G+ 370 Share on Facebook 104 Share on Twitter Total Shares577 Editorials Pixel Pixel XL The Google Pixel is a notoriously hard phone to get a hold of. Persistent stock issues have plagued Google's first "in-house" handset from day one, and things really are little to no better six months after the launch event. Honestly, it's a bit embarrassing just how consistently incompetent Google seems to be at keeping a reasonable inventory of phones available for purchase. But setting that aside, as one of the Pixel's most ardent evangelists, I think there's something it's probably time for me to come clean on: Even if you could buy a Pixel today, I really think you shouldn't. The Pixel is a product with generation-one product issues. The Bluetooth performance is horrid. It's not waterproof. The bezels really are due for a shrink. I don't think the exterior coating on the black and blue variants is of a particularly high quality. The glass window gets scuffed up incredibly easily. The Snapdragon 821 is officially old news. And it doesn't support proper advanced network features across all four of the big US carriers. There are other flaws I could point to, and while none of them are too terrible, they do speak to the slightly-rushed development cycle this phone seems to have been subjected to. Sure, Google got some things astoundingly¬†right: the performance, the camera, the larger software experience. In fact, I think the Pixel is easily the best Android smartphone ever for these strengths, at least if we're talking about me personally as a user (your mileage, obviously, may vary). But for all the great, smooth, fast, clean, pure, simple, natural, and various other adjective-members singing in the Pixel-praise cavalcade, this phone is not the one to buy right now. For starters, Google continues to ask what is an increasingly laughable amount of money for the model most of us want - the 128GB XL - at a staggering $870. Sure, Apple charges the same for an iPhone 7 Plus 128GB, but I'm under no illusion that this comparison in any way favors Google. The iPhone comes with Apple customer service (with actual stores), a longer software support period going forward, and runs no real risk of poor resale value. The Pixel? Google's online support is iffy at best, we know the phone will be unsupported by October 2018, and I have a strong feeling generation-one Pixel resale values will drop like a rock once the new phones are announced. And that really is why, if you haven't pulled the trigger on a Pixel yet, you should just wait. It's overpriced, under-supported, and competing phones like the Galaxy S8 offer a whole lot more technology for your money. The Galaxy S8+ is $20 less than a 128GB Pixel XL, and I would argue it is far and away the better smartphone value. That amazing display, brand-new Snapdragon 835 processor, jaw-dropping design and packaging, and the full support of all our American carriers' latest LTE advancements could each be a reason on its own to put the Galaxy S8 above Google's smartphone. Do I still prefer using the Pixel over the S8? Sure. But I wouldn't buy a 128GB Pixel XL over a Galaxy S8+ today. That would be, frankly, a bit silly. If Google was asking $670 and not $870, the discussion would probably change, but they aren't. You've got to pay full price, and there's no way I could recommend anyone do that. If you're still on the fence about the Pixel, let me try to push you over: wait for the next generation. I realize that this sort of thinking can devolve into a rationale that encourages you to never upgrade anything because something newer, faster, and better is constantly on the horizon. But in this case, I think it's a consideration that is worth weighing more seriously than usual. Many of the Pixel's biggest flaws relate to Google's inexperience producing a smartphone. Issues that only come up as you try to mass-produce and distribute a product with a real marketing campaign that creates real demand, and the phone gets into the hands of "real" users who aren't part of the now-derailed Nexus phone hypetrain. Inside Google, expectations were no doubt managed, realities realized, and priorities accordingly re-calibrated after this first launch. (Side note: if the Bluetooth performance on the next Pixel is as bad as the first one, I may scream, Google.) Meanwhile, the things that make the Pixel great aren't going anywhere. The next Pixel will be fast, it will take great photos, and it will offer a wonderfully unfettered Android experience. Those that make it less than great? Google is no doubt drilling down through the worst of them in order to ensure the Pixel 2 - or whatever it's called - won't¬†make the same mistakes that the original did (waterproofing, please). And one of the primary reasons to try the Pixel in the first place - to be on the very bleeding edge - really only remains true from a software standpoint. Older phones like the Nexus 5X and 6P don't even let the Pixel have an advantage there, as they're on the same update track until around the time the next Pixel phones launch. If you absolutely need a smartphone soon and the Pixel is tempting you, ask yourself this: Can you deal with a Moto G5 Plus for six months if it means having a better Pixel down the road? While as a reviewer I have the admitted luxury of not needing to consider such things, were I in such a position, I'd have little in the way of a counterargument to offer. Sure, you'll take a resale hit on anything you buy now, but the Pixel is going to face a much, much steeper devaluation curve in that time than any budget phone. Buying a Pixel right now just doesn't make sense. I love my Pixel XL, but I'm officially done recommending the phone to friends and relatives. Instead, I'll tell them to wait, or to get the Galaxy S8 they were probably going to buy anyway. Tags editorial google pixel google pixel xl opinion pixel xl subscribe ... Before A Troll Does The Best Add-Ons For Protecting Your Gmail Account Intel Says Their New SSD Is The World‚Äôs Most Responsive Toggle navigation Life Money Home Entertainment Travel Health Design Work Productivity Communicate Organise Career Business Travel Security Small Business & Startups IT Pro Cloud IT Career IT Security Developer Deployment Servers Build Your Own Adobe Creative Suite With Free And Cheap Software Six Essential Life Lessons From The Making Of Star Wars How To Repurpose Fruit Skin Into Salt And Sugar How To Watch The 2017 Eurovision Song Contest In Australia Online And Free Make Your Phone Safer To Drive With These Handy Tips David Nield May 7, 2017, 8:00am ‚ãÖ Filed to:¬† cars driving road safety safety smartphones Share Many road incidents have been caused by smartphones, one of the most prominent distractions there is while driving. Avoid adding to the problem by setting your mobile up for safe operation when you're on the road ‚Äî here are some basic tips. Image: Google Setting up an iPhone If you're an iPhone user, Siri is your best friend as a driver. It lets you tell your phone what you need instead of having to peck at the screen with your fingers and take your eyes off the road while you're doing it. To get "hey Siri" to work at any time in any app on iOS devices, open Settings then tap Siri and toggle the Allow "Hey Siri" switch to on. On anything older than an iPhone 6s, the phone has to be plugged into a power supply before the voice shortcut is going to work, so you might need a car charger. Siri can come in handy in all kinds of ways while you're driving: "hey Siri, read out my messages" for example. You can make calls, send messages, get navigation directions and more besides ‚Äî ask Siri "what can you do?" to see a full list (while you're parked). You should also think about whether you really need alerts to be on while you're driving. Before you set off, swipe up on the home screen to bring up the Control Center, and you can enable either aeroplane mode (no incoming alerts at all) or the Do Not Disturb mode (muted alerts). Head to the Do Not Disturb section in the iOS Settings app and you can allow calls from certain contacts to break through this wall of silence. There are a select number of third-party apps that can make your drive safer too. LifeSaver, for example, locks up the display while you're on the move and rewards you for resisting the temptation to tamper with it, and SafeDrive takes a similar gamified approach. Another option is AT&T DriveMode, which can limit outside communications, gives you one-touch access to key apps, and can even reply to your incoming texts for you. Setting up an Android phone The big tip for drivers using Google-powered handsets is to get Android Auto installed. The app is now available for any Android 5.0+ phone, no head unit required, and brings with it oversized widgets, simplified icons, a streamlined interface and a focus on voice control for all of the key interactions you need. There are smart touches throughout, like the option to send an "I'm driving at the moment" text reply at the push of a button, and support for launching the Android Auto interface automatically when certain Bluetooth devices (like your car stereo) are detected. It makes Android even more pro-active too, automatically showing navigation buttons for places you've recently looked up on Google Maps, while music and podcast apps (including Spotify and Google Play Music) get stripped-down, chunky interfaces as well. There are other tweaks you can apply, with or without Android Auto. For example, you can enable the "OK Google" voice command so it works at any time in any app. Choose Settings, Voice and then "OK Google" detection from the menu inside the Google app. Commands you can try while you're driving cover everything from "call Mum" to "directions to 1414 Colusa Avenue, Indooroopilly, Queensland". As on the iPhone, Android includes aeroplane mode and a Do Not Disturb function (under Sound in Settings), so you can choose to mute your handset or switch off connectivity altogether ‚Äî remember that Google Maps can cache directions and maps in advance, so you can still find your way somewhere. Finally, there are third-party apps you can consider installing too. Drive Safe can respond to texts automatically, while SafeDrive blocks all of your phone's alerts until your speed drops back down under 16km-an-hour. Drivemode, like Android Auto, is based around a simplified, "no look" interface that you can operate using your voice or some basic on-screen swipes, and then there's OneTap, which aims to be a smart, personal driving assistant. Not only can it launch itself automatically when you start driving, it also logs all the notifications it's suppressed on your behalf, and can be configured to let alerts through from 'emergency' contacts. But why bother trying to hunt down another console when the smartphone in your pocket can already do almost everything the Switch can -- with a few upgrades. Build Your Own Adobe Creative Suite With Free And Cheap Software Thorin Klosowski 05 May 2017 4:30 PM Adobe's Creative Suite is one of the best software packs out there for professionals, but the suite is prohibitively expensive for most people - and it's about to get even pricier in Australia. If you can't drop the cash, you can still get a similar experience with free or cheap software. Here's how to build your own Creative Suite. Want Lifehacker's email newsletter? Subscribe Have a tip? Weather Your 4-day local weather forecast Sunday May 7, 2017 Life & Style Technology Larger / SmallerNight Mode VR app lets you see through the eyes of person with dementia Tim Biggs 22 Sep 2016, 2:35 p.m. A new virtual reality app that puts users in the position of a person living with dementia has been released for Google's Cardboard VR platform. VR app lets you see through the eyes of person with dementia Carers trying out EDIE at the Alzheimer's Australia launch event in Melbourne. Photo: Arsineh Houspian A screenshot from the EDIE VR app. Dr Ron Petersen from the Mayo Clinic in the US tries out the EDIE app at the launch event. Photo: Arsineh Houspian Tweet Facebook of ‚ï≥ exit A new virtual reality app that puts users in the position of a person living with dementia has been released for Google's Cardboard VR platform. Called EDIE (pronounced Eddy put standing for Educational Dementia Immersive Experience), the app was launched on Thursday by Alzheimer's Australia Vic, and is available free on Android and iPhone. Dr Tanya Petrovich, manager of business development at Alzheimer's Australia Vic, says the app was designed to build empathy and make people more aware of the issues faced by those living with Dementia. "The idea is you step into the shoes of a person named Edie, who's living at home with his wife, and who is living with dementia", Petrovich says. When Edie gets up in the middle of the night and has to go to the bathroom, players see the world through his eyes. Petrovich says that many people think of Alzheimer's as only affecting the memory, but that it actually has a much broader range of symptoms. With EDIE, the user will get an approximation of the changes in sensory perception that may be experienced by a person living with dementia. "Perception is a really big issue", Petrovich says. "For you and me a pattern is easy to distinguish, but for a person living with dementia a pattern can appear to be moving, or it could even appear to be an animal. It could appear to be cockroaches or ants". It might even appear that a larger animal or person is in the room, when in reality it's just a pattern on the wall, Petrovich said. She added that while this is known to happen to some people living with dementia, every person is different and symptoms vary. In addition to memory, dementia can affect mood, language, problem solving and the ability to plan, although a virtual reality platform presents an ideal way to explain its effect on perception. Petrovich says the free app is an example of the kind of tool Alzheimer's Australia uses when training carers. Later this year, a workshop called Enabling Edie will use the app as a training tool. Carers will experience the same scene featured in the public version but with a second scene that shows how, after his carer makes a few changes, the environment could become more supportive for Edie. EDIE can be used with any VR viewer compatible with Cardboard. A number of low-cost viewers can be purchased through Google, and Alzheimer's Australia Vic is selling its own EDIE branded viewer for $15. September is Dementia Awareness Month. Help and more information can be found at fightdementia.org.au/vic or by calling the National Dementia Helpline on 1800 100 500. Home carers and health professionals interested in signing up for the EDIE workshop can do so at vic.fightdementia.org.au/edie. The story VR app lets you see through the eyes of person with dementia first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald. Enter your search terms Submit search form ¬† ¬† ¬† Home | About Us | Sample Press Release ¬† Press Release Articles | Press Releases and SEO | Press Release Book ¬† ¬† The Deep End Launches new YouTube Series "My Website Sucks" ¬† View as PDF ¬†Print View ¬†¬† The new web series by TheDeepEndDesign.com focuses on businesses with lackluster web presences and solutions for making their site shine Chicago, IL - May 6, 2017 /MarketersMedia/ -- Websites that rank on the first page of Google search engine results receive 91.5 percent of traffic. The majority of people don't venture past the first page of results and if a website is on the second page, it only receives 4.8 percent of search traffic. Having a well-developed and properly optimized business website is more important today for businesses that want to be found than it has ever been in the past. In an effort to help businesses that have lackluster search results, The Deep End Web Consulting is looking for participants for a new YouTube series "My Website Sucks." The series will focus on business owners who want free advice and help for their website. Those who volunteer will be featured on this 10 episode web series. "The new series we are creating will consist of ten individual episodes, with our expert team evaluating the current site a business uses," stated company representative Wes McDowell. "Once the current site has been assessed, we will provide quick and actionable advice related to how to improve the site and start making their business more money." Without a great ranking on the first page of Google SERPs, businesses can't expect to compete in today's market. Google has 64 percent of the market share for desktop users, with Microsoft coming in second at 21 percent and Yahoo at just 12.5 percent. Without an effective strategy to rank well, businesses may find their potential business is going to their competition. "Our entire business is focused on helping businesses attract more visitors, convince visitors to stay on the website longer and convert visitors to actual customers," McDowell continued. "Our most recent effort is going to provide free help and advice to businesses who may be hesitant to invest in their digital presence. When they see the difference that a bit of work can provide, our hope is that they will retain our services on a longer-term basis." Businesses throughout the country need to invest in their web presence and take steps to improve their digital profile. With the latest efforts offered by The Deep End Web Consulting, this is now possible at no cost to business owners. ABOUT THE DEEP END WEB CONSULTING The Deep End Web Consulting specializes in helping businesses achieve results-driven solutions for small and medium businesses. The company takes cues from the businesses they work with to come up with solutions that meet the specific needs of their clients. Dedicated to on-going customer success, The Deep End Web Consulting company provides solutions that get results. Contact Info: Name: Wes McDowell Organization: The Deep End Web Consulting Address: Chicago, IL 60613 Phone: 310-387-6611 Source URL: http://marketersmedia.com/the-deep-end-launches-new-youtube-series-my-website-sucks/194674 For more information, please visit http://Thedeependdesign.com Source: MarketersMedia Release ID: 194674 Recent Press Releases By The Same User Funxim Unveils Wireless Smartphone Charging Product: Moonsonata (Sun 7th May 17) Scrap Metal Company, Research Alloys Co. Finance Search Search Warren BuffettWarren Buffett Says Berkshire Hathaway Stock May Start Paying Dividends Warren BuffettWarren Buffett Says Artificial Intelligence Will ‚ÄòHurt‚Äô Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs Business Kentucky DerbyHow to Bet on the Kentucky Derby Online TelevisionThe FCC Is Reviewing Stephen Colbert‚Äôs Trump Joke. But What Can It Actually Do? Berkshire Hathaway 2017 Warren Buffett: Not Buying Google Is Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs Biggest Mistake Jen Wieczner May 06, 2017 At the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting Saturday, CEO Warren Buffett made a startling admission. After surprising investors recently with his giant bet on Apple stock, the Oracle of Omaha‚Äîlong averse to Silicon Valley companies‚Äîsays he now wishes he'd bought more technology stocks when he had the chance. Apple (aapl) has been Buffett's greatest hit over the past year, boosting Berkshire's portfolio by about $2 billion in 2017 alone after the investor loaded up on more of the iPhone maker's stock. Now, Buffett is kicking himself for not taking advantage of the opportunity to buy stock in Google (googl) shortly after it went public more than a dozen years ago. The founders of the company now called Alphabet even came to see Buffett shortly after the tech company's IPO with an investment prospectus, but the legendary stock-picker passed. "I knew the guys," Buffett said at the Berkshire Hathaway (brk.a) meeting. "And so I had plenty of ways to ask questions or anything of the sort and educate myself, but I blew it." Buffett's business partner and Berkshire Hathaway vice chairman Charlie Munger regrets that decision even more. "If you asked me in retrospect what was our worst mistake in the tech field," that was it, Munger said at the meeting. "I think we were smart enough to figure out Google‚Äîthose ads worked so much better in the early days than anything else‚Äîso I would say that we failed you there," Munger said. "We were smart enough to do it, and we didn‚Äôt do it." In fact, Berkshire's insurance subsidiary Geico was an early customer of Google, buying ads on the search engine for "$10 to $11 a click," so the investors had a front row seat seat to the business' growth, Buffett said. "Any time you're paying somebody $10 or $11 when somebody just punches a little thing where you‚Äôve got no cost at all, that‚Äôs a good business," he added. "You‚Äôve almost never seen a business like it." Warren BuffettWarren Buffett Says Berkshire Hathaway Stock May Start Paying Dividends Warren BuffettWarren Buffett Says Artificial Intelligence Will ‚ÄòHurt‚Äô Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs Business Warren BuffettWarren Buffett‚Äôs Stocks Made $16 Billion Since the Last Berkshire Hathaway Meeting Warren BuffettHow to Watch Warren Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting Live Stream debit cardsSquare Starts Rolling Out Its Own Debit Card Warren BuffettIBM Set to Drop $5 Billion in Value After Warren Buffett Sheds a Third of His Stake JobsU.S. Jobs Bounced Back in April After a Disappointing March Warren BuffettWarren Buffett‚Äôs Outlook for the Economy Hasn‚Äôt Changed Since 2009 Explaining his decision to invest in Apple after so many years of steering clear of the tech industry, Buffett said he sees the company as less of a technology company than a consumer products company (as opposed to IBM (ibm), whose stock the investor announced that he is selling this week). But Buffett also noted a fundamental change in the market that has made him see tech differently, observing that the five most valuable American companies are now worth a whopping more than $2.5 trillion combined. Those five companies, in order of market value, are Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft (msft), Amazon (amzn) and Facebook (fb). "And if you take those five companies, essentially you could run them with no equity capital at all," Buffett said. "You literally don‚Äôt need any money to run the five companies that are collectively worth more than $2.5 trillion." "That is a different world than what existed in the past," he added, comparing the "capital-light" nature of Internet and cloud computing companies to the capital-intensive industrial and steel businesses that he invested in earlier in his career. "But this is so much better if you happen to be good at it." Given his views on the compelling case for those companies, a shareholder asked Buffett during the annual meeting's Q&A why Berkshire had never invested in Amazon. "I was too dumb to realize what was going to happen," Buffett responded, saying he "never even considered" buying Amazon stock, despite his great respect for the e-commerce company's founder, Jeff Bezos. "I admired Jeff but I did not think he‚Äôd succeed on the scale that he has," Buffett said, noting that Amazon's lucrative foray into the cloud services business never occurred to him a few years ago. "I really underestimated the brilliance of the execution." But for Berkshire's executives, the one that got away, so to speak, is really Alphabet. "I don‚Äôt feel any regret about missing out on the achievements of Amazon," Munger said. "Other things were easy, and I think we screwed up a little." When Buffett declined to comment on those screw-ups, Munger clarified: "I meant Google." In the future, though, Berkshire is likely to make more bets on tech, Munger hinted. "I think it‚Äôs a very good sign that you bought the Apple stock," Munger told Buffett. "It shows either one of two things: Either you‚Äôve gone crazy or you're learning. I prefer the learning explanation." Customer ServiceSite MapPrivacy PolicyAdvertisingAd ChoicesTerms of UseYour California Privacy RightsCareers ¬© 2017 Time Inc. All rights reserved. ¬† Home ¬† ¬† U.K. News Sports U.S. Showbiz Australia Femail Health Science Money Video Travel Columnists Latest headlines World News You mag Event Books Mail Shop Bingo Property Horoscopes Blogs Motoring My Profile Logout Login Feedback DailyMail NEW ARTICLESHomeTop Share show ad Together in electronic streams: Are you a Spotify guy or a Deezer geezer? Here‚Äôs all the vital info you need By Rob Waugh Event for The Mail on Sunday Published: 17:06 EDT, 6 May 2017 | Updated: 17:06 EDT, 6 May 2017 e-mail View comments Like eBooks, streaming music services are difficult to really love. There‚Äôs no equivalent to that delicious crackle of cellophane as you unwrap a gatefold, special-edition vinyl double disc. But, also like eBooks, I use streaming services because I‚Äôm a dyed-in-the-wool skinflint.¬† With streaming ‚Äì playing music over the internet instead of buying a hard copy ‚Äì there is no danger of building up a really splendid music collection only to find the format is declared ‚Äòdead‚Äô, and no one makes the players any more. Yes, I‚Äôll admit I am still pretty bitter about my extensive MiniDisc collection. But streaming isn‚Äôt going to disappear any time soon.¬† You can listen to Taylor Swift on Apple Music and Amazon Music (although not Spotify, due to people being able to use it free) The Rolling Stones (left) and Rihanna (right) Katy Perry (left) and Neil Young (right)¬† Beyonce in concert for the 'Formation: World Tour' at Qualcomm Stadium, San Diego Ed Sheeran is a popular artist for millions of streaming app users¬† The music industry saw a five per cent rise in profits in 2016, after years of shattering losses ‚Äì and the rise has been driven by people streaming music. There are now 100 million paying users worldwide.¬† If you‚Äôre using a smartphone to listen to music, streaming apps are by far the easiest way to get music on your phone ‚Äì and allow you to load up as many albums as you want without having to painstakingly transfer files from a PC.¬† Most artists who initially refused to stream their music ‚Äì such as Bob Dylan ‚Äì have now caved in, and you can even listen to Taylor Swift on Apple Music and Amazon Music (although not Spotify, due to people being able to use it free).¬† RELATED ARTICLES Previous 1 Next 'Ingeniously plotted and immaculately performed': The... Neeme J√§rvi and his¬†Estonian National Symphony Orchestra... Share this article Share New family plans mean you can have up to six users on one account ‚Äì so you no longer need to suffer the indignity of being kicked off your music when your children want to listen to Katy Perry. But how do you choose a streaming service?¬† At first glance they all seem identical, with millions of tracks that can be played either via your PC, mobile phone or tablet.¬† Even the pricing is similar, with free services offering music with occasional adverts in between the tracks, and paid-for subscriptions offering the chance to stream higher-quality tracks, with no ads, and download them to your device for listening offline. But there are crucial differences, with some streaming CD-quality music ‚Äì and some not.¬† They also differ in how easy it is to find new music. Some recommend music based on your tastes ‚Äì and even where you are, with Google‚Äôs Play offering playlists for ‚Äòwork‚Äô and ‚Äòhome‚Äô. So which is¬†best for you? ¬† APPLE MUSIC¬† Price ¬£9.99 per month (¬£14.99 for family of six)¬† Maximum sound quality 256kbps¬† Songs 40 million¬† Free version No¬† Best feature¬†Great if you have lots of iTunes tracks Downside Not so great¬†for non Apple users. ¬† Apple‚Äôs service has evolved into a sophisticated, high-gloss app that, typically of Apple, is slickly designed and intuitive to use.¬† If you‚Äôve got a sizeable collection of music bought from iTunes over the years, it‚Äôs great, as you can access those files from anywhere, as well as the 40 million tracks offered by Apple Music ‚Äì and Apple uses your music tastes to recommend other songs you might like.¬† The software on desktop PCs is a little ugly, but it works well on¬†iPhone (and even Android). GOOGLE PLAY MUSIC¬† Price ¬£9.99 (¬£14.99 for family of six)¬† Maximum sound quality 320kbps¬† Songs 40 million¬† Free version No¬† Best feature¬†Upload your own tracks Downside Big Brotherstyle¬†snooping. ¬† Google‚Äôs service is a polished juggernaut, topped up with slightly spooky features, such as ‚Äòknowing‚Äô when you‚Äôre at home, and recommending music to unwind to (it does this using your phone‚Äôs sensors and Google‚Äôs alarming store of data).¬† The colourful app is easy to use ‚Äì and you can upload 50,000 of your own tracks to listen to anywhere. Just like in Google Search, there‚Äôs an ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Feeling Lucky‚Äô button, which brings up a radio station based on your music taste .¬† SPOTIFY Price ¬£9.99 (¬£14.99 for family of six) Maximum sound quality 320kbps Songs 30 million Free version Yes, with adverts Best feature Lots of ways to find new music Downside¬†Fewer tracks than its rivals. ¬† ¬† Spotify has been going for nine years, making it the grandfather of streaming music. It feels extremely polished and excels at recommending you new music, with daily updated playlists based on your previous listening, divided by genres you like.¬† If you‚Äôre on a family plan, each member gets their own daily mix. Initially, it‚Äôs irritating having a computer ‚ÄòDJ‚Äô your music ‚Äì but the system works well and¬†you swiftly fall into listening to them.¬† DEEZER¬† Price ¬£9.99 (¬£14.99 for family of six) Maximum sound quality 1,411 kbps¬†(with Deezer Elite for Sonos users) Songs 43 million Free version Yes, with adverts Best feature Works well with Sonos hi-fis Downside¬†Clunkier than Spotify. ¬† Deezer does it all ‚Äì with a freebie version, and also hi-fi-friendly hi-res files, although the catch is that you‚Äôll need to own a Sonos sound system to take advantage of the high-quality ‚ÄòDeezer Elite‚Äô service, as well as paying ¬£14.99 a month for the privilege. Another cute extra is live sports commentary ‚Äì including Premiership games ‚Äì delivered via TalkSport. TIDAL Price ¬£9.99 (¬£19.99 for Tidal Hi-Fi) Maximum sound quality 1,411 kbps Songs 47 million Free version No Best feature CD-quality sound Downside¬†The top-end version is very expensive. ¬† Tidal was relaunched with ridiculous fanfare by Jay-Z and a small army of his celebrity friends ‚Äì but it‚Äôs actually less awful than that makes it sound. The big sell here is high-quality sound ‚Äì CD-quality, or even above, with some albums available at similar sound quality to the ‚Äòmaster‚Äô recordings used in studios.¬† There‚Äôs also a pleasing emphasis on playlists created by humans ‚Äì with compilations curated by musicians.¬†¬† AMAZON MUSIC¬† Price ¬£9.99 (¬£14.99 for family of six) Maximum sound quality 256kbps Songs 40 million Free version No Best feature Great with Echo Downside¬†Fewer good recommendations. ¬† Amazon‚Äôs music service is a great option if you‚Äôve already climbed on board with Amazon Prime ‚Äì or you own an Echo smart speaker. It‚Äôs ¬£9.99 a month, ¬£7.99 for Prime users, and ¬£3.99 for Echo users.¬† Sound quality is great, and it works with voice control. It‚Äôs less clever at recommending music than Spotify and¬†Google Play Music, though. ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Share or comment on this article e-mail Comments 0 Share what you think No comments have so far been submitted. The Google Home has a built-in library of relaxing ambient audio Paul Quinn Follow View All Posts 2017/05/06 7:26am PDTMay 6, 2017 37 Plus 1 on G+ 56 Share on Facebook 55 Share on Twitter Total Shares148 Google Home Videos Update¬†1: 2017/05/06 10:12am PDT While Google's support page says the feature is limited to Google Homes in United States, there are reports of it working outside 'Murica as well. Feeling like you want to relax after you've finished that meal you prepared with Google Home's help? Overwhelmed by your Home's answer to what's on your schedule tomorrow? Just ask it¬†to help you relax with some soothing ambient sounds. Currently offering a catalog of 15 different ambient sound themes, Google Home can now replace your sound machine. The ambient sound themes include nature sounds, water sounds, fireplace sounds, and country sounds. The latter of those is crickets, lots of crickets. The ocean sounds theme must be based on heavy seas because I found that one a little too stimulating. If you're feeling lucky (that's Google Play Music lingo), you can just say, "Help me relax," and your Google Home will select a theme for you. Do you want to fall asleep to relaxing sounds? No problem. You can tell your Google Home to play one of these relaxing themes for a specified amount of time. For example, you can say, "Hey Google, play forest sounds for two hours." You'll hear the sounds of the forest for two hours, and then your Home will slowly fade out the audio. If you don't specify a time limit, it will default to one hour. Google has even included this helpful video on their support page. Let Tech With Brett take it away. Google notes that you can press and hold your finger on the top of the device to activate your Google Home instead of speaking the wake word. I'm not sure what the advantage of this is because you still need to speak your request to play an ambient sound theme. If you are going to talk to your Home anyway, you might as well wake it with your voice too. I can already imagine combining these sounds with Hue lighting scenes to create my own voice activated relaxation chamber. Source: Google Update¬†1: 2017/05/06 10:12am PDT While Google's support page says the feature is limited to Google Homes in United States, there are reports of it working outside 'Murica as well. Indiatimes|The Times of India|The Economic Times : HI, My Times LOGOUTSign In City More Beauty Pageants Photos Videos More Fashion Specials Debate Photos Videos Platinum Times of India More HomeHome Videos City India World Business Tech Cricket Sports Entertainment TV Life & Style Photos TIMES NEWS - RADIO Elections 2017 Delhi MCD 2017 Brandwire Yearender 2016 Good Governance City METRO CITIES Mumbai Delhi Bangalore Hyderabad Kolkata Chennai OTHER CITIES Agartala Agra Imphal Ahmedabad Allahabad Amritsar Aurangabad Bareilly Bhopal Bhubaneswar Chandigarh Coimbatore Cuttack Dehradun Erode Faridabad Goa Gurgaon Guwahati Hubli Indore Jaipur Jammu Jamshedpur Jind Kanpur Kochi Kolhapur Kozhikode Lucknow Ludhiana Madurai Mangalore Meerut Mysore Nagpur Nashik Navi Mumbai Noida Patna Puducherry Pune Raipur Rajahmundry Rajkot Ranchi Srinagar Salem Shillong Shimla Surat Thane Trichy Thiruvananthapuram Vadodara Varanasi Visakhapatnam Pune Crime Civic Issues Politics Schools & Colleges Events Delhi MCD Polls 2017 ALL News ¬ª City News ¬ª Pune News ¬ª Pitroda says buck stops with websites Pitroda says buck stops with websites TNN | Updated: May 7, 2017, 12.00 AM IST Pune: Companies such as Google, Facebook and other social media platforms should take responsibility for content on their sites, technocrat and policymaker Sam Pitroda said on Saturday. He and a few other individuals across the globe have come together under the aegis of Association for Accountability and Internet Democracy (AAID) in Paris to demand "protection of private integrity and societal value" on the Internet. "Twenty of us from all over the world have come together and we want big companies like Facebook and Google to take responsibility for their content," Pitroda said while addressing a gathering of Pune International Centre members and others at the College of Engineering here. He said unlike newspapers, big companies like Google and Facebook do not take responsibility for their content. "If newspapers publish incorrect information, they will apologise. On the other hand, Google and Facebook won't even remove the content. So, this has been bothering us for quite some time," he said. Pitroda said that there is concern over a lot of misinformation, gossip and vendetta on social media. "By design, people propagate misinformation because it gets them more hits," the technology veteran added. The man, who also served as advisor to former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, said some people hire publicists to tweet on their behalf. "There is a difference between propaganda and information," said the man who is credited with laying the telecommunication roadmap for the country in the 1980s. He stressed the need for a new design to the world order in the Internet age and said India - because of its value system, family bonds and social cohesion - is best suited to build that design. "World can only be redesigned by Indians but we are not ready to take on a task like this because our house is not in order. Today, the world is waiting for India to take the lead. People want family values, love, compassion -- all of which India has and also it has costumes, colour, food, diversity. No other country has that kind of diversity. To hold a country with so much diversity without guns is one of India's greatest accomplishments," he added.
